text: I was 44 years old and it was a massive
shock massive
you know what am I going to read when am
I going to eat what plate will I eat or
you know sort of you know is that too
much is that too little you know it's
sort of like me it dominates shall I
throw very much you didn't believe that
this could be happening to somebody
who's your age no it doesn't happen to
old people and it definitely didn't
happen to me
the accepted wisdom is that eating
disorders strike young but Julie and
Chris are two of a growing number of
older people with anorexia for me being
that age and being diagnosed I really
felt that I should have known better
while the overall rate of eating
disorders is thought to be in decline
research carried out by breakfast shows
that in older age groups it is
significantly increasing the number of
people in their 60s receiving specialist
outpatient treatment increased by almost
a quarter over the last four years for
those in their 50s there was a sharper
increase of almost a third last year one
in every six who received specialist
treatment were over 40 why might this be
will in some cases like Chris it is
patients who have slipped through the
net over previous decades if you don't
get treatment early on then recovery
becomes but experts we've spoken to
believe that in many cases like Julie's
the illness has struck late in life out
of the blue I knew I wasn't eating I
knew I was depressed but I had no idea
that I couldn't physically eat in the
four years I lost two-thirds of my body
weight I lost my husband and my job and
I almost lost my life we showed our
findings to Age UK who said eating
disorders for older people are a serious
issue and often overlooked by health
professionals there is a need for better
awareness and support in treatment which
is largely focused on the young if there
were people that were a similar age that
I've got a connection with I would
acknowledge that this does happen to
people like me it's not just young
people that suffer the government is
investing in the area but only to
improve services for the young in a
statement they say we are investing 150
million to develop services for children
and young people and have set targets
for their care there are also plans to
develop standards that will improve
care for adults with eating disorders
certainly the last women hospital it
really brought me face-to-face with what
I lost to anybody he was like funding
treating or anything like that I'd say
give those people of charge give them
the treatment now because it's gonna
stop
